ygData.subject: Re: Publish and be damned?
ygData.msgSnippet: At most journals and conferences, anyone should be able to publish. I d suggest starting with conferences, such as GECCO (Genetic and Evolutionary Computation

At most journals and conferences, anyone should be able to publish.  
I'd s=
uggest starting with conferences, such as GECCO (Genetic and 
Evolutionary =
Computation Conference).  A good journal is a loooong 
process that can tak=
e more than a year or even  years before the 
paper ever sees print.  For c=
onferences you need to check the 
deadlines for submission and prepare acco=
rdingly.  For journals 
there is no deadline.

Conferences like GECCO are d=
ouble-blind, which means reviewers don't 
get to see the author's name or a=
ffiliation, and the author doesn't 
get to know who the reviewer was.  So y=
our lack of affiliation 
should have no impact.  However, you may want to g=
ive yourself some 
kind of "made up" affiliation, like a company or laborat=
ory name, 
for when it goes into print.  Derek and Philip on this group bot=
h 
did that and have published late breaking papers at GECCO.  They 
have e=
xperience in trying to publish without academic affiliation, 
so they may b=
e able to give you some perspective.  

Note that the main barrier to indep=
endent publishing in research is 
not lack of affiliation.  In my opinion, =
it is style.  It took me 
years to learn the acceptable manner of speech, s=
ectional divisions, 
order of exposition, etc., for this community.  And I =
had the 
benefit of a veteran (Risto) constantly correcting and rewording 
=
everything I wrote.  Without that, you may end up sounding like you 
are an=
 outsider.

And that's a subtle problem, because being able to write good p=
rose 
is not the same as knowing the customs and conventions of a 
particul=
ar research community.  Researchers can tell when non-
researchers submit p=
apers because they break all the conventions 
unwittingly.  

So the conclu=
sion is that you need to be really careful about 
following the conventions=
 of your predecessors.  It is not 
impossible to do, but it is a point most=
 people outside academic 
communities don't appreciate since they don't nec=
essarily realize 
that there is such a strong set of conventions.  

ken

-=
